entry.title: Flood Warning issued December 5 at 7:17PM CST by NWS Lake Charles LA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Louisiana...
Calcasieu River Near Glenmora
.Additional rainfall this weekend will likely produce higher stages than are currently forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Friday evening at 730 PM CST.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Calcasieu River near Glenmora.
* WHEN...From late tonight until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Some roads upstream from Glenmora, including Strothers Crossing Road near the community of Calcasieu and Price Crossing Road near Hineston have two to three feet of water over the road and are subject to being closed. Flooding of forested areas near the river will also occur.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:45 PM CST Thursday the stage was 11.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage just after midnight tonight and continue rising to a crest of 14.0 feet early Sunday morning. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Rapides, LA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 5 at 7:49PM EST by NWS Gaylord MI
entry.summary: Lake effect snow showers will continue downwind of Lake Michigan this evening, primarily targeting areas along the US-131 corridor and points west. This would include areas such as Kalkaska, Mancelona, Traverse City and Elk Rapids. The snow showers will reduce visibility to 1 mile or less at times. One to three inches of snow accumulation are possible within the most persistent snow shower activity. If traveling this evening across this area, be aware of the possibility of quick reductions in visibility and slick roads. Slow down and use caution.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Leelanau; Antrim; Benzie; Grand Traverse; Kalkaska; Manistee; Wexford; Missaukee; Charlevoix

cap:parameter.value: Lake Effect Snow Showers Resulting in Reduced Visibility

entry.title: Dense Fog Advisory issued December 5 at 5:37PM MST until December 6 at 11:00AM MST by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Visibility one quarter mile or less in dense fog.
* WHERE...Northern Wasatch Front, Salt Lake Valley, and Tooele Valley. Especially along routes close to the Great Salt Lake including I-80 between Salt Lake City and Grantsville, and routes west of I-15 including the Legacy Highway and the West Davis Corridor.
* WHEN...Until 11 AM MST Friday.
* IMPACTS...Low visibility could make driving conditions hazardous. When driving into the fog bank, expect rapidly deteriorating conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Higher elevation locations, including benches, mainly along and east of I-15, as well as the west Salt Lake Valley bench are largely expected to remain out of the dense fog.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Tooele and Rush Valleys; Northern Wasatch Front; Salt Lake Valley

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 5 at 3:31PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary: After snow this morning and this afternoon, snow will taper off this evening. Expect accumulating snow to diminish and visibility to improve from Fairbanks and the Richardson Highway to the south and west by 5 pm. Snow showers will linger north of Fairbanks, and visibility may be reduced to as low as 1 mile at times during the evening commute. Expect snow to move north of Hilltop to Cleary Summit by 7 pm at the latest.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Upper Chena River Valley; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Chatanika River Valley; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 5 at 7:22PM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
At 716 PM EST, an area of light to moderate lake effect snow showers was impacting parts of eastern Erie County, northeastern Huron County, Lorain County, northeastern Ashland County, Medina County, Wayne County, Summit County, Stark County, Portage County, southern Trumbull County and Mahoning County.
HAZARDS INCLUDE... Winds up to 30 mph causing some blowing and drifting snow... Visibility dropping as low as one-half of a mile... Additional snow accumulations of 1 to 3 inches through midnight...
Locations impacted include... Akron, Canton, Youngstown, Lorain, Elyria, Warren, Medina, Wooster, Sandusky, Norwalk, Salem, Ravenna, Western Vermilion, Vermilion, Columbiana, Cuyahoga Falls, Boardman, Brunswick, Massillon, and North Ridgeville.
Light snow accumulations on area roadways are likely this evening, with untreated surfaces becoming slick and icy. Motorists should be prepared for slick and snowy road conditions this evening and allow extra time to reach their destination if they must travel.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Erie; Lorain; Huron; Medina; Summit; Portage; Trumbull; Ashland; Wayne; Stark; Mahoning; Holmes

cap:parameter.value: Lake Effect Snow Showers Producing Variable Travel Conditions This Evening

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 5 at 3:16PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Patchy to areas of fog reducing visibility to a half mile of less have developed along portions of the Sterling Highway this afternoon from Sterling south to about Ninilchik. Given cold roadways, fog may create slick spots along the highway, especially in locations that have temperatures at or below freezing. The fog is expected to dissipate within the next hour or two as higher level clouds move into the western Kenai Peninsula and Cook Inlet; however, some patchy fog may continue to linger into the overnight hours for a few locations.
If driving, be prepared for rapidly changing visibility and possible slick spots on roadways. If you encounter fog, slow down, use your headlights, and leave plenty of distance ahead of you.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Kenai Peninsula

cap:parameter.value: PATCHY TO AREAS OF FOG ALONG PORTIONS OF THE STERLING HIGHWAY THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Dense Fog Advisory issued December 5 at 4:03PM PST until December 6 at 11:00AM PST by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Air Stagnation Advisory, light winds and limited air movement will lead to a period of stagnant air conditions. This scenario could result in the build up of air pollutants over time. For the Dense Fog Advisory, visibility frequently below one quarter mile in dense fog and areas of freezing fog.
* WHERE...South Willamette Valley.
* WHEN...For the Air Stagnation Advisory, until 4 AM PST Saturday. For the Dense Fog Advisory, until 11 AM PST Friday.
* IMPACTS...Poor air quality may cause issues for people with respiratory problems. Low visibility could make driving conditions hazardous.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Fog will reform and increase across the south Willamette Valley this evening. Overall, temperatures will hold at or just above freezing overnight. But, a few spots will drop back below freezing. As such, motorists should be prepared for potentially icy or slick spots, especially on less-traveled rural roadways and bridges.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Benton County Lowlands; Linn County Lowlands; Lane County Lowlands

cap:parameter.value: AIR STAGNATION ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 AM PST SATURDAY... ...DENSE FOG ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 AM PST FRIDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 5 at 2:42PM AKST until December 6 at 12:00PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Freezing rain expected. Total ice accumulation of a light glaze.
* WHERE...Anchorage and Matanuska Valley.
* WHEN...Until noon AKST Friday.
* IMPACTS...The hazardous conditions could impact the morning commute. Any melted liquid on untreated could refreeze.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Despite the break in precipitation this afternoon (Thursday), another round of freezing rain and drizzle is expected to move through the Anchorage and Matanuska Valley areas after midnight tonight into Friday morning. Precipitation coverage and rainfall amounts are expected to be lighter than before. Any additional precipitation is likely freeze on untreated surfaces and any residual water that is on the ground will refreeze once the sun sets and surface temperatures dip below freezing.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Anchorage; Matanuska Valley

entry.title: Flood Watch issued December 5 at 1:31PM AKST until December 6 at 9:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
A low and associated front will move across the area Thursday night bringing more moderate to heavy rain across the region. The rain combined with a melting snowpack and high freezing levels will continue to provide runoff for area rivers and streams that are already running at an elevated level. The heaviest rainfall amounts will occur from the late evening through early morning hours.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues to be possible.
* WHERE...The following area, Central Inner Channels. This includes the city of Juneau.
* WHEN...Through Friday morning.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, low-lying areas and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Storm drains and ditches may become clogged with debris. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Heavy rain will fall on the existing snowpack leading to increased runoff. Rivers already experiencing elevated flows may see increases and reach impactful levels. Between 0.75 to an 1.25 inches of rain with localized higher amounts is possible through Thursday morning.
- Storm drains should be kept clear of debris as much as possible.
entry.cap:areaDesc: City and Borough of Juneau

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH FRIDAY MORNING

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued December 5 at 1:55PM PST by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The South Coast AQMD has extended a mandatory wood-burning ban for residents in the South Coast Air Basin. The No-Burn rule bans burning wood, pellets, and manufactured fire logs in any indoor or outdoor wood-burning device.
* WHERE...The South Coast Air Basin, which includes Orange County and non-desert portions of Los Angeles, Riverside, and San Bernardino counties. No-Burn Day alerts do not apply to areas above 3,000 feet in elevation, the Coachella Valley, or the High Desert. Homes that rely on wood as a sole source of heat, low-income households and those without natural gas service also are exempt from the requirement.
* WHEN...until 11:59PM Friday.
* IMPACTS...Particles in smoke can get deep into the lungs and cause health problems (including asthma attacks), increases in emergency room visits, and hospitalizations. No-Burn Days are needed to protect public health when fine particle pollution levels are expected to be high anywhere in the South Coast Air Basin. No-Burn Days are based on fine particle pollution levels that are forecasted for an entire 24-hour period, which may not be reflected in real- time air quality maps.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Bernardino and Riverside County Valleys-The Inland Empire; Riverside County Mountains; San Gorgonio Pass Near Banning; Orange County Coastal; Orange County Inland

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued December 5 at 10:24AM PST by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
ESFSEW
A stronger storm system will bring heavier rainfall to the northern and central portions of the Cascades in Washington this weekend. While uncertainty with respect to flood potential at individual river points remains high, confidence in heavier rainfall setting up across the mountains of Whatcom, Skagit, and Snohomish counties has increased. If the middle to high end forecast rainfall amounts occur, minor flooding is possible on rivers draining from the Cascades in these areas. Snow levels will remain quite high during the bulk of the heavy precipitation, ranging between 7000 and 9000 feet.
Please monitor the latest river forecasts from the National Weather Service for additional information.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Skagit, WA; Snohomish, WA; Whatcom, WA

cap:parameter.value: THREAT OF RIVER FLOODING SATURDAY AND SUNDAY FOR WHATCOM, SKAGIT, AND SNOHOMISH COUNTIES

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued December 5 at 10:24AM PST by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
ESFSEW
A stronger storm system will move though the area over much of the weekend that could produce enough rainfall to drive the Skokomish River above flood stage. There is still a fair amount of uncertainty regarding flooding since the precipitation forecasts have been quite variable. On the low end, it would not produce a flood, but on the high end minor flooding would be likely. Snow levels will remain quite high during the bulk of the heavy precipitation, ranging between 7000 and 9000 feet.
Please monitor the latest river forecasts from the National Weather Service for additional information.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Mason, WA

cap:parameter.value: THREAT OF RIVER FLOODING SATURDAY MORNING THROUGH SUNDAY FOR MASON COUNTY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 5 at 11:52AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
Following the passage of a dry cold front later this morning, relative humidity will fall into the 20 to 30 percent range across the North Carolina Piedmont and foothills this afternoon. Winds will gust in the 20 to 25 mph range from the west and northwest throughout the day. Fine fuel moisture is expected to dry out quickly during the late morning and early afternoon. These conditions will be conducive for the quick formation and spread of wildfires.
Based upon coordination with local land managers and forestry officials, a Fire Danger Statement remains in effect for NC Forest Service Districts 2, 10, and 12. Consult your local burn- permitting authority to determine whether you may burn outdoors. If you do burn, exercise extreme caution.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued December 4 at 1:09PM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The South Coast AQMD has extended a mandatory wood-burning ban for residents in the South Coast Air Basin. The No-Burn rule bans burning wood, pellets, and manufactured fire logs in any indoor or outdoor wood-burning device.
* WHERE...The South Coast Air Basin, which includes Orange County and non-desert portions of Los Angeles, Riverside, and San Bernardino counties. No-Burn Day alerts do not apply to areas above 3,000 feet in elevation, the Coachella Valley, or the High Desert. Homes that rely on wood as a sole source of heat, low-income households and those without natural gas service also are exempt from the requirement.
* WHEN...until 11:59PM Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Particles in smoke can get deep into the lungs and cause health problems (including asthma attacks), increases in emergency room visits, and hospitalizations. No-Burn Days are needed to protect public health when fine particle pollution levels are expected to be high anywhere in the South Coast Air Basin. No- Burn Days are based on fine particle pollution levels that are forecasted for an entire 24-hour period, which may not be reflected in real-time air quality maps.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Catalina and Santa Barbara Islands; Santa Clarita Valley; Malibu Coast; Los Angeles County Beaches; Palos Verdes Hills; Los Angeles County Inland Coast including Downtown Los Angeles; Western Santa Monica Mountains Recreational Area; Eastern Santa Monica Mountains Recreational Area; Calabasas and Agoura Hills; Western San Fernando Valley; Eastern San Fernando Valley; Santa Susana Mountains; Los Angeles County San Gabriel Valley

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued December 4 at 11:37AM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Pollution Advisory...in effect until 10 AM PST Thursday.
The Oregon Department of Environmental Quality issued an air quality advisory for Lake County. Check current air quality conditions and advisories on DEQs Air Quality Index or by downloading the OregonAIR on your app on your smartphone.
Many county health and local air agencies have also issued wood burning restrictions limiting the use of wood stoves, fireplaces and outdoor burning. There are often exceptions for those who use wood exclusively to heat their homes and those with limited income. Check with your local heath or air agency for current restrictions.
People can take the following precautions to protect their health:
- Follow local burn restrictions to prevent deteriorating air quality. - Avoid strenuous outdoor activity during periods of poor air quality. - People with heart or lung problems and young children are especially vulnerable. These people should stay indoors while smoke levels are high. - Use certified High Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) filters in indoor heating, ventilation, cooling and air purification systems. - Avoid using wood-burning stoves and other sources of indoor smoke if possible.
DEQs color-coded Air Quality Index provides current air quality conditions and ranks air quality as follows: Green is good. Yellow is moderate. Orange is unhealthy for sensitive groups such as children, the elderly, pregnant women and those with respiratory conditions. Red is unhealthy for everyone. Purple is very unhealthy for all groups. Maroon is hazardous.
For additional information...please visit the web site at https://oregonsmoke.org
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake, OR
